assessment.title: Major Functions of the Integumentary System

body.p: What system does the integumentary system not directly support?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The skin can act with the nervous system to sense temperature and pressure (touch).
Incorrect. The integumentary system plays an important immune function by acting as a barrier to foreign organisms.
Incorrect. This may not be obvious, but the vitamin D synthesis in the skin helps with bone health.
Correct. The skin is mostly disconnected from the digestive system.

body.p: Exposure of the skin to sunlight is required for:

response.feedback: Correct. While you can ingest vitamin D to get it, the only way for your body to process it is through the absorption of sunlight.
Incorrect. Osmotic balance does not require exposure of the skin to sunlight.
Incorrect. Lipids are stored regardless of exposure to sunlight.
Incorrect. If we were cold-blooded, we would need the sunlight for heat production, but we are warm-blooded.

body.p: Accumulation of fats in the hypodermis:

multiple_choice.choice: may be required for brain function
acts as an energy storage mechanism

response.feedback: Incorrect. Keratinocytes are cells that make up the top layer of skin.
Incorrect. Although the brain does require fats to function correctly, the fats stored in the hypodermis are used for energy storage, protection and insulation.
Correct. The adipose tissue of the hypodermis stores lipids, which contain a lot of energy in their chemical bonds.
Incorrect. The fat stored in the hypodermis is not involved in hair growth.
